headline.print_headline: Sharp Drop in Rates of Breast Cancer Holds
headline.main: Sharp Drop in Rates of Breast Cancer Holds

docs.lead_paragraph: The most likely reason for the fall in rates, the investigators said, was that large numbers of women stopped taking hormone therapy for menopause.
docs.snippet: The most likely reason for the fall in rates, the investigators said, was that large numbers of women stopped taking hormone therapy for menopause.

headline.main: Sharp Drop in Rates of Breast Cancer Holds

docs.abstract: Researchers from MD Anderson Cancer Center say in 2003 and 2004 there were nearly 10 percent fewer breast cancer cases than expected; say it is first substantial drop in breast cancer incidence in more than quarter century; reduction involved women age 50 and older; researchers say most likely reason for fall in rates is that large numbers of women stopped taking hormone therapy for menopause; therapy, combination of estrogen and progestins can increase incidence of breast cancer (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Breast cancer rates fell sharply in 2003, and the lower rate remained in 2004, researchers are reporting today. The finding, they say, fits with a hypothesis they advanced last December when they had data only from 2003. At that time, national data showed that breast cancer rates fell by nearly 15 percent in the 18 months from July 2002 through December 2003.
docs.snippet: Breast cancer rates fell sharply in 2003, and the lower rate remained in 2004, researchers are reporting today.      The finding, they say, fits with a hypothesis they advanced last December when they had data only from 2003. At that time, national...

docs.abstract: Some high-end spas are offering DNA analysis as ultimate and most intimate evolution in personalized care; many offer recommendations or products based on variations in certain genes; while there is little proof that such personalized products can make difference, it makes sense that they might, given thousands of subtle variations in genetic functions that affect health and aging; clinical relevance of such testing discussed; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: It is possible to get many things at the Four Seasons Hotel in Westlake Village, Calif., but a blood-and-urine panel that analyzes the condition of your DNA is a relatively new development. The panel, offered through the California WellBeing Institute as part of several luxury-lifestyle packages, including a $2,800 executive physical, is boomingly popular: about 50 people signed up in January, the first month it was available.

headline.main: A Year After Smoking Ban, Many Cheers, Some Doubts

docs.abstract: Health officials say air quality has improved greatly in restaurants and office buildings in year since New Jersey's smoke-free-air act took effect; New Jersey Restaurant Assn says results have been mixed for its members (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Since New Jersey's smoke-free-air act went into effect a year ago, air quality in restaurants and office buildings has improved greatly, health officials said last week. But a state group that represents bars and restaurants still has misgivings. Fred M. Jacobs, commissioner of the State Department of Health and Senior Services, called the ban, which began a year ago today, ''a giant step forward in public health prevention.''
